abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts. Lessons nonetheless
            convey the following. Lending for development policy should
            not rely on conditionality alone to catalyze, and implement
            reforms. The Government should be made fully aware of the
            technical and financial requirements of each agreed reform
            at the identification stage of the operation, in order to
            facilitate implementation later. Thus, to be fully
            successful, the implementation of policy must be supported
            by other instruments that provide technical assistance, and
            help build country capacity step by step. This backstopping
            should be coordinated with key development partners in the
            donor community, because the Bank's resources are
            limited. Lessons further highlight that the tension between
            performance and macroeconomic stability should be
            anticipated, for the cost of slippages to macro stability is
            higher in Sierra Leone because there are only four budget
            support donors - delays on the part of one donor mean
            roughly 25 percent less budget support. In this context, it
            is useful to acknowledge that the all or nothing
            requirements for the release of funds utilized by the
            project, created an incentive to complete reforms, yet
            macroeconomic stability was reduced when weak capacity
            slowed the achievement of required actions. In essence, the
            design of the credit did not fully anticipate the delays
            that are likely to occur in post-conflict states. Lessons
            further emphasize the need to find an empowered leader from
            within Government to coordinate implementation of the reform
            program, and a champion to lead the reform program. Most
            importantly, a comprehensive program of capacity building by
            the Government should be accomplished, through recruitment
            and training programs, especially in-house training to
            ensure valued staff remain on-hand as needed.
